Massachusetts General Laws, chapter 186,.proposition: This is an action for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts General Laws, chapter 186, section 14, based on the Defendant’s failure to provide hot water to the Plaintiff's rental unit for an extended period of time.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 1.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 1.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 8.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 8, as the events giving rise to this claim occurred in Brockton, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, tenants are entitled to the covenant of quiet enjoyment pursuant to G.L. c. 186, § 14.

*Dartmouth Harness v. Borkowski*, 452 Ma.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment requires landlords to maintain leased premises in a condition fit for human habitation, including providing essential services such as hot water.
*Dartmouth Harness v. Borkowski*, 452 Ma.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns the constitutionality and application of the Massachusetts reckless endangerment of a child statute and the adequacy of a jury trial waiver. It does not address landlord–tenant law, the covenant of quiet enjoyment, habitability standards, or the provision of essential services such as hot water. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for the claimed proposition about the covenant of quiet enjoyment.

*Jablonski v. Casey*, 64 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The failure to provide hot water for an extended period of time constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Jablonski v. Casey*, 64 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss hot water at all, nor does it contain any holding that the absence of hot water constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Instead, it affirms a finding that there was no breach of quiet enjoyment on the specific facts, and the only reference to hot water is in a parenthetical summarizing a different case (Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas) as an example of serious defects. Thus, this case does not itself establish the proposition claimed.
*Jablonski v. Casey*, 64 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “We have interpreted this obligation to mean that the covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant from serious interference with her tenancy. See Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Authy., 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994). … The trial judge did not err in denying the requested ruling of law that a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment had occurred. We see no evidence in the record before us of interference with Casey’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.”

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102-03.proposition: Defendant’s failure to restore hot water to the premises materially interfered with Plaintiff’s use and enjoyment of her rental unit.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102-03.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses lack of hot water only in quoting the text of G.L. c. 186, § 14, as one of several possible ‘essential services’; the facts, analysis, and holdings concern flooding and unsanitary water/sewage conditions, not a failure to restore hot water. Nowhere does the court find that a lack of hot water in this case interfered with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of her unit, nor does it analyze such a situation. Therefore this case does not provide authority for the specific proposition about failure to restore hot water materially interfering with use and enjoyment.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102-03.relevant_excerpt:
In relevant part, G. L. c. 186, § 14, as amended through St. 1974, c. 192, § 1, provides that:

“Any lessor or landlord of any building or part thereof occupied for dwelling purposes ... who is required by law or by the express or implied terms of any contract or lease or tenancy at will to furnish water, hot water, heat, light, power, gas, elevator service, telephone service, janitor service or refrigeration service to any occupant of such building or part thereof, who willfully or intentionally fails to furnish such water, hot water, heat, light, power, gas, elevator service, telephone service, janitor service or refrigeration service at any time when the same is necessary to the proper or customary use of such building or part thereof...”

*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855, 866.proposition: Defendant’s breaches were not occasioned by conditions beyond his control but instead reflect an unreasonable delay in repairing the property.
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855, 866.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses Haddad’s failure to repair severe code violations and his disregard of court orders, but it does not frame that conduct in terms of whether the breaches were ‘occasioned by conditions beyond his control’ versus ‘unreasonable delay’ in repair. The case is about liability for habitability, quiet enjoyment, emotional distress, and c. 93A damages, not about excusing or justifying delay based on external conditions. Thus it does not expressly support the specific proposition stated.
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855, 866.relevant_excerpt: “In late August, 1983, an inspector reinspected the apartment in the presence of both parties. The inspector found that virtually all of the defects identified by the judge remained unrepaired. Later that month, the Boston inspection services department served Haddad with three separate notices of violations of State and city housing regulations related to the condition of Gonzalez's apartment. On September 9, 1983, the inspector again made an inspection of the premises and reported that unrepaired defects remained.”

*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.raw_text: *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273, 283 (1994)
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.proposition: Defendant’s failure to comply with G.L. c. 186, § 14 entitles Plaintiff to actual damages, emotional distress damages, attorney’s fees, and potentially punitive damages for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion construes G.L. c. 186, § 14 as creating liability and expressly notes that prevailing tenants are entitled to costs and reasonable attorney’s fees, and potentially injunctive relief. It does not, however, mention or authorize emotional distress damages or punitive damages under § 14 in this case. The case therefore supports the availability of attorney’s fees (and judgment/injunctive relief for breach of quiet enjoyment) but does not support the broader proposition that a failure to comply with § 14 entitles the plaintiff to emotional distress damages and punitive damages.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “If the defendant has taken no action or inadequate action, despite covenanting that the plaintiffs’ right to quiet enjoyment shall not be interfered with, then the plaintiffs will be entitled to judgment, appropriate injunctive relief, costs and reasonable attorney’s fees. See G. L. c. 186, § 14.”

*Bosse v. O'Connor*, 30 Mass. App. Ct. 6.proposition: Defendant’s ongoing failures to repair the water heater constitute a "substantial interference with quiet enjoyment," as recognized by G.L. c. 186, § 14 and cases such as *Bosse v. O'Connor*, 30 Mass. App. Ct. 602, 604 (1991).
*Bosse v. O'Connor*, 30 Mass. App. Ct. 6.support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal drug-trafficking case concerning search and seizure, mistrial, and ineffective assistance of counsel. It does not involve landlord-tenant law, G.L. c. 186, § 14, quiet enjoyment, or any discussion of failures to repair utilities or conditions of tenancy. Citing this case for the proposition that ongoing failures to repair a water heater constitute substantial interference with quiet enjoyment is inaccurate and unsupported by the decision’s holdings or reasoning.
*Bosse v. O'Connor*, 30 Mass. App. Ct. 6.relevant_excerpt:
The conviction of trafficking in cocaine based on the seizure of cocaine at the time of the defendant’s warrantless arrest is affirmed. The conviction of trafficking in cocaine based on the seizure of cocaine at the defendant’s residence is reversed and the verdict is set aside.

So ordered.
